questions.prompt: Which novel opens with: "You will rejoice to hear that no disaster has accompanied the commencement..."?
choices: The Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde
questions.explanation: It’s the first line of Mary Shelley’s epistolary novel Frankenstein.

questions.prompt: Which novel begins: "Miss Brooke had that kind of beauty which seems to be thrown into relief..."?
questions.explanation: This is the opening line of George Eliot’s Middlemarch.

questions.prompt: Which work opens with: "As Gregor Samsa awoke from a night of uneasy dreaming..."?
questions.explanation: Kafka’s The Metamorphosis begins with Gregor Samsa’s transformation.

questions.prompt: Which novel starts: "Someone must have slandered Josef K., for one morning... he was arrested."?
questions.explanation: That’s the famous opening of Franz Kafka’s The Trial.

questions.prompt: Which novel begins: "Stately, plump Buck Mulligan came from the stairhead..."?
choices: A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man
questions.explanation: James Joyce opens Ulysses with Buck Mulligan’s entrance.

questions.prompt: Which novel opens with: "Well, Prince, so Genoa and Lucca are now just family estates..."?
questions.explanation: This is the opening line of Leo Tolstoy’s War and Peace.

questions.prompt: Which novel begins: "He was an old man who fished alone in a skiff in the Gulf Stream..."?
choices: The Old Man and the Sea
questions.explanation: Ernest Hemingway’s The Old Man and the Sea opens this way.

questions.prompt: Which novel starts with: "Okonkwo was well known throughout the nine villages..."?
questions.explanation: Chinua Achebe introduces Okonkwo at the start of Things Fall Apart.

questions.prompt: Which novel begins: "When he was nearly thirteen, my brother Jem got his arm badly broken..."?
questions.explanation: Harper Lee opens To Kill a Mockingbird with Jem’s broken arm as a framing device.

questions.prompt: Which novel starts: "The Time Traveller (for so it will be convenient to speak of him)..."?
choices: Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Seas
questions.explanation: H. G. Wells opens The Time Machine by naming “the Time Traveller.”

questions.prompt: Which book opens with: "One thing was certain, that the white kitten had nothing to do with it..."?
questions.explanation: Lewis Carroll begins Through the Looking-Glass with the kittens’ “mischief.”

questions.prompt: Which novel opens: "No one would have believed... that this world was being watched..."?
choices: The First Men in the Moon
questions.explanation: The ominous opening belongs to H. G. Wells’s The War of the Worlds.

questions.prompt: Which story begins: "To Sherlock Holmes she is always the woman."?
questions.explanation: Arthur Conan Doyle opens “A Scandal in Bohemia” with Holmes’s view of Irene Adler.

questions.prompt: Which novel begins: "Through the fence, between the curling flower spaces, I could see them hitting."?
questions.explanation: William Faulkner opens The Sound and the Fury with Benjy’s perspective.

questions.prompt: Which novel begins: "When a day that you happen to know is Wednesday starts off by sounding like Sunday..."?
questions.explanation: That’s the disorienting opening of John Wyndham’s The Day of the Triffids.

questions.prompt: Which novel opens with: "'Take my camel, dear,' said my aunt Dot..."?
questions.explanation: Rose Macaulay’s The Towers of Trebizond starts with this comic line.

questions.prompt: Which novel begins: "The sweat wis lashing oafay Sick Boy; he wis trembling."?
questions.explanation: Irvine Welsh opens Trainspotting in Scots dialect.

questions.prompt: Which novel opens (in part): "I wish either my father or my mother... had minded what they were about..."?
questions.explanation: Laurence Sterne’s Tristram Shandy begins with a famously digressive complaint about conception.

questions.prompt: Which book begins: "When I wrote the following pages... I lived alone, in the woods..."?
questions.explanation: Henry David Thoreau opens Walden by describing his life at Walden Pond.

questions.prompt: Which novel opens: "Once upon a time when the world was young there was a Martian named Smith."?
questions.explanation: Robert A. Heinlein begins Stranger in a Strange Land with Valentine Michael Smith.

questions.prompt: Which work begins: "There was Eru, the One, who in Arda is called Ilúvatar..."?
questions.explanation: J. R. R. Tolkien opens The Silmarillion with the Ainulindalë and Eru Ilúvatar.

questions.prompt: Which novel opens: "His name was Gaal Dornick and he was just a country boy..."?
questions.explanation: Isaac Asimov’s Foundation begins by introducing Gaal Dornick.

questions.prompt: Which novel begins: "The Galactic Empire was dying."?
questions.explanation: This blunt opener starts Asimov’s Foundation and Empire.

questions.prompt: Which novel opens: "It was a wrong number that started it..."?
questions.explanation: Paul Auster starts City of Glass with a misdialed call that triggers the plot.

questions.prompt: Which novel begins with the description: "He was an inch, perhaps two, under six feet, powerfully built..."?
questions.explanation: Joseph Conrad opens Lord Jim with a portrait of Jim’s physical presence.

questions.prompt: Which novella begins: "A few miles south of Soledad, the Salinas River drops in close..."?
questions.explanation: John Steinbeck sets the scene for Of Mice and Men along the Salinas River.

questions.prompt: Which novel begins: "I am the vampire Lestat."?
questions.explanation: Anne Rice’s The Vampire Lestat opens with Lestat’s direct introduction.

questions.prompt: Which novel opens with the triple question: "Where now? Who now? When now?"?
questions.explanation: Samuel Beckett opens The Unnamable with these disorienting questions.

questions.prompt: Which novel opens: "I returned from the City about three o'clock on that May afternoon..."?
questions.explanation: John Buchan begins The Thirty-Nine Steps with Richard Hannay back from London.

questions.prompt: Which novel begins: "Late in the afternoon of a chilly day in February, two gentlemen were sitting..."?
questions.explanation: Harriet Beecher Stowe opens Uncle Tom’s Cabin with two men in a Kentucky parlor.

questions.prompt: Which novel opens: "People do not give it credence that a fourteen-year-old girl could leave home..."?
questions.explanation: Charles Portis begins True Grit with Mattie Ross’s matter-of-fact narration.

questions.prompt: Which novel begins: "Behind every man now alive stand thirty ghosts..."?
questions.explanation: Arthur C. Clarke opens 2001: A Space Odyssey with this population/ancestry observation.

questions.prompt: Which novel opens: "Granted: I AM an inmate of a mental hospital..."?
choices: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
questions.explanation: Günter Grass begins The Tin Drum with a self-conscious, conspiratorial narrator.

questions.prompt: Which novel opens: "Every summer Lin Kong returned to Goose Village to divorce his wife..."?
questions.explanation: Ha Jin opens Waiting with Lin Kong’s annual, bureaucratic attempt at divorce.

questions.prompt: Which novel begins: "The bench on which Dobbs was sitting was not so good."?
choices: The Treasure of the Sierra Madre
questions.explanation: B. Traven opens The Treasure of the Sierra Madre with Dobbs on an uncomfortable bench.

questions.prompt: Which novel begins: "He was born with the gift of laughter and a sense that the world was mad."?
questions.explanation: Rafael Sabatini begins Scaramouche with this line about André-Louis Moreau.

questions.prompt: Which novel opens: "'To be born again,' sang Gibreel Farishta... 'first you have to die.'"?
questions.explanation: Salman Rushdie opens The Satanic Verses with Gibreel Farishta falling from the sky.

questions.prompt: Which novel ends with: "So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly..."?
questions.explanation: F. Scott Fitzgerald closes The Great Gatsby with this famous line.

questions.prompt: Which novella opens: "Mother died today. Or maybe yesterday; I can't be sure."?
questions.explanation: Albert Camus begins The Stranger (L'Étranger) with Meursault’s detached announcement.

questions.prompt: "Better to reign in Hell, than serve in Heaven." is from which work?
questions.explanation: The line is from John Milton’s epic poem Paradise Lost (Book I).
